channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ukraine Live Updates: Russia Moves to Stabilize Its Economy as War Takes a Toll
item.description: The country’s central bank cut interest rates again as President Vladimir V. Putin moved to raise the minimum wage and sweeten military benefits. Two Russian soldiers pleaded guilty in the second war crimes trial in Ukraine since the fighting began.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers from the 95th Air Assault Brigade loaded a weapon onto an armored vehicle near the city of Kramatorsk, Ukraine, on Wednesday.

item.title: Colombia Election: Angry, Mobilized and Voting for Gustavo Petro
item.description: A large and loud youth electorate hungry to transform one of Latin America’s most unequal societies could propel Gustavo Petro, a former rebel, to the presidency.
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: A rally for presidential candidate Gustavo Petro in Cartagena, Colombia on May 14.

item.title: South Korean Workers Turn the Tables on Their Bad Bosses
item.description: “South Koreans live with an enormous tolerance for abuse” from the powerful, said one famously bullied advocate. A backlash has erupted.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Park Chang-jin, a former Korean Air flight attendant who campaigns against abusive behavior at work, participating in a protest rally for a temporary worker who died in an industrial accident in South Korea.

item.title: Senegal Hospital Fire Kills 11 Infants, President Says
item.description: President Macky Sall said the blaze broke out in a neonatal unit, but gave no further details.
item.dc:creator: Yonette Joseph
item.media:description: President Macky Sall of Senegal at a news conference in Dakar, the capital, this month.

item.title: India Heat Wave’s Lamented Victim: The Mango, a King of Fruits
item.description: Blistering spring temperatures have devastated crops of the country’s most beloved fruit. “The soul of a farmer shudders at seeing these fruitless trees,” one grower said.
item.dc:creator: Suhasini Raj
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: Zubair Ahmed, a third-generation mango farmer, inspecting raw mangoes in his orchard in Malihabad, India, this month.

item.title: China Seeks Sweeping Regional Deal With Pacific Island Countries
item.description: Newly obtained documents shed light on how Beijing hopes to win friends and gain influence in an area of strategic importance.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:description: The Chinese embassy in Nuku’alofa, Tonga. China is pursuing a regional agreement with 10 Pacific island nations.

item.title: Film on Expulsion of Kashmir’s Hindus Is Polarizing and Popular in India
item.description: Called propaganda by critics and essential viewing by fans, “The Kashmir Files,” an unexpected blockbuster, has drawn the support of Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s Bharatiya Janata Party.
item.dc:creator: Suhasini Raj
item.media:description: An advertisement for the “The Kashmir Files” outside a theater in the old quarters of Delhi in March.

item.title: Gambia Says It Will Prosecute Former President for Murder
item.description: Victims of Yahya Jammeh, who ruled the West African country for 22 years, welcomed the announcement but said exactly how he will be brought to justice is not clear.
item.dc:creator: Saikou Jammeh and Ruth Maclean
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Yahya Jammeh, then the president of Gambia, campaigning in 2016.

item.title: Israel Tells U.S. It Killed Iranian Officer, Official Says
item.description: Israeli officials say the officer, Sayad Khodayee, was a leader of a covert unit tasked with abductions and killings of Israelis and other foreigners around the world. Iran does not acknowledge that the unit exists.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Ronen Bergman
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: The funeral of Sayad Khodayee, a colonel in Iran’s Revolutionary Guards Corps, in Tehran on Tuesday.

item.title: Johnson Says He’s Humbled by ‘Partygate’ Report but Will Go On
item.description: The long-awaited report on boozy parties that violated lockdown rules was once seen as potentially ruinous for Prime Minister Boris Johnson, but the situation has changed.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler, Stephen Castle and Megan Specia
item.media:description: A policeman stands guard outside the prime minister’s residence in London on Wednesday.

item.title: North Korea Launches Suspected ICBM and Two Other Ballistic Missiles
item.description: The tests came just as President Biden wrapped up a trip to the region with a promise to deter the North’s nuclear and missile threat.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, Via Reuters
item.media:description: An undated photo released by North Korean state media showing the country’s leader, Kim Jong-un, next to what was reported to be a Hwasong-17 intercontinental ballistic missile.

item.title: How (and Why) We Calculated the Value of Haiti’s Payments to France
item.description: We wanted to know how much Haiti had paid over generations. So we set out to compile the data.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut

item.title: Europe Greets Monkeypox With a Touch of Fatalism
item.description: With war raging in Ukraine, and the coronavirus still circulating, many in Europe say they have bigger worries than monkeypox. Some organizations, however, have raised concerns about stigma.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai and Emma Bubola
item.category: European Center for Disease Prevention and Control
item.media:description: Working on a monkeypox vaccine at a laboratory near Munich, Germany, on Tuesday.

item.title: Who Is Protected Against Monkeypox?
item.description: Older people who received smallpox vaccinations may yet have some immunity, researchers say. Healthy children and adults generally do not become severely ill.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:description: A laboratory of the biotech company Bavarian Nordic, which produces a smallpox vaccine that is also effective against monkeypox.

item.title: America’s Gun Problem
item.description: More guns in the U.S. mean more deaths.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Ivan Pierre Aguirre for The New York Times
item.media:description: Prayers at Robb Elementary School.

item.title: Concern Grows in China Over Economic Impact of ‘Zero Covid’
item.description: A senior leader announced efforts to bolster growth and urged local leaders do more to keep the economy running.
item.dc:creator: Paul Mozur and Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:description: The lockdown in Shanghai and sporadic lockdowns elsewhere have had vast repercussions for China’s economy.

item.title: Through a Recession and a Pandemic, the Book Business Is Thriving in Buenos Aires
item.description: The Argentine capital has always been bookish. When hard times shuttered the big chain shops, book purveyors found a way to keep residents in fresh reading material.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Politi
item.media:credit: Magali Druscovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: Carime Morales opened her bookstore, Malatesta, in 2021; it has become a stoping point for neighbors.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: New details from a deadly shooting.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Ivan Pierre Aguirre for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mourners at Robb Elementary School on Wednesday.

item.title: Other Countries Had Mass Shootings. Then They Changed Their Gun Laws.
item.description: Britain, Australia, Canada, New Zealand, Norway: All had a culture of gun ownership, and all tightened restrictions anyway. Their violence statistics now diverge sharply from those of the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Max Fisher
item.media:credit: Mark Felix for The New York Times
item.media:description: A prayer vigil for the victims of the Uvalde Elementary School shooting held in downtown Houston on Tuesday.

item.title: These U.S. Schools and Universities Are Reimposing Indoor Mask Mandates
item.description: The moves are a sign that while the academic year may be coming to a close, the pandemic is still not.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra E. Petri
item.media:credit: Alejandro A. Alvarez/The Philadelphia Inquirer, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Schools in Philadelphia restored their mask mandate on Monday.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: A Texas School Shooting
item.description: Plus Russia’s narrowed focus and diplomacy in Africa.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg and Lynsey Chutel
item.media:credit: Ivan Pierre Aguirre for The New York Times
item.media:description: A group of men embrace and pray at the entrance of Robb Elementary School on Wednesday in Uvalde, Texas.

item.title: E. Gerald Corrigan, Who Helped Ease ’87 Stock Crash, Dies at 80
item.description: As president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, he favored flooding the financial system with cash to restore confidence among investors.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts
item.category: Federal Reserve Bank of New York
item.media:description: E. Gerald Corrigan outside the Goldman Sachs building in Manhattan in 2005. He joined Goldman Sachs after an eventful tenure as president of the New York Federal Reserve Bank.

item.title: In the U.S., Backlash to Civil Rights Era Made Guns a Political Third Rail
item.description: Other countries changed course after massacres. But American political protection for guns is unique, and has become inseparable from conservative credentials.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:credit: Christopher Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: A gunman attacked Robb Elementary School in Uvalde, Texas, on Tuesday.

item.title: A Doomed River Crossing Shows the Perils of Entrapment in the War’s East
item.description: Encirclement is a tactic used by both sides in the war between Russia and Ukraine, but it can carry big risks.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Ivor Prickett
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett/ The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier atop an abandoned Russian tank in the Seversky Donets river in order to salvage a heavy machine gun left behind, on Wednesday.

item.title: Dozens of Migrants Die After Boat Sinks Off Tunisian Coast
item.description: The vessel carried about 100 people and had left from a Libyan port city.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:description: Earlier in the week, another group of migrants was rescued by the Libyan Coast Guard.

item.title: ‘Quantum Internet’ Inches Closer With Advance in Data Teleportation
item.description: Scientists have improved their ability to send quantum information across distant computers — and have taken another step toward the network of the future.
item.dc:creator: Cade Metz

item.title: Putin Visits the Wounded at a Military Hospital in Moscow
item.description: The Russian leader also announces new social welfare measures and military benefits in an apparent effort to show Russians he is aware times are tough.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia visited a military hospital in Moscow on Wednesday, as seen in this photograph provided by Russian state-run media.

item.title: E.P.A. to Block Pebble Mine Project in Alaska
item.description: The E.P.A. has proposed to ban the disposal of mining waste in the Bristol Bay watershed, a decision that very likely means the end of the Pebble Mine project.
item.dc:creator: Coral Davenport
item.media:credit: Acacia Johnson for The New York Times
item.media:description: The town of Dillingham, Alaska, faces the open waters of Bristol Bay.

item.title: Read the Full U.K. Lockdown Parties Report
item.description: Sue Gray’s inquiry into illicit lockdown parties in Downing Street was released on Wednesday.
item.media:description: The report on alleged lockdown parties in Downing Street included evidence that Mr. Johnson had attended a birthday party held for him.

item.title: 19 Murdered Children
item.description: Gun violence has killed more children and destroyed another community.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: Mourners in Uvalde, Texas.

item.title: The Downing Street lockdown parties ‘represent a serious failure,’ a report says.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson has pledged to make the report publicly available after it is submitted.

item.title: After Biden Visit, China Organizes Military Drills Near Taiwan
item.description: After President Biden suggested the United States would get involved militarily to defend Taiwan if China attacked it, China described organizing combat drills in the seas and airspace around Taiwan.
item.dc:creator: Paul Mozur and John Liu
item.media:description: A view of the South China Sea between the city of Xiamen in China, in the far distance, and the islands of Kinmen in Taiwan, in the foreground.

item.title: Corporations Pledge to Buy ‘Green’ at Davos Gathering
item.description: A global buyers’ club of more than 50 companies, including Microsoft and Ford Motor, say they will buy “green” steel, aluminum and other commodities by 2030.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:description: John Kerry, left, the U.S. special climate envoy, with Borge Brende, center, the president of the World Economic Forum, and Xie Zhenhua, Mr. Kerry’s Chinese counterpart, at the World Economic Forum in Switzerland on Tuesday.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: A deadly school shooting.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Families outside the Civic Center in Uvalde, Texas, where students from Robb Elementary School were transported.

item.title: U.S. Speeds Up Reshaping of Taiwan’s Defenses to Deter China
item.description: The Biden administration is taking lessons from the war in Ukraine to turn Taiwan into a “porcupine” bristling with weapons that would inflict severe pain if attacked.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: F-16 fighter jets in Chiayi, Taiwan. Chinese leaders face a complicated calculus in weighing whether their military can seize Taiwan without incurring an overwhelming cost.

item.title: Law Requiring French in Quebec Becomes Stricter
item.description: Quebec’s new law limits access to government services in languages other than French, requires small businesses to operate in it and caps enrollment at English-language junior colleges.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Quebec Premier François Legault during a news conference in Montreal, last year.

item.title: Glencore Will Pay $1.1 Billion to Settle Bribery and Price-Fixing Charges
item.description: U.S. prosecutors said the settlement followed “a multiyear scheme to manipulate benchmarks used to set prices for oil at two of our country’s busiest ports.”
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush
item.media:description: “The rule of law requires that there not be one rule for the powerful and another for the powerless, one rule for the rich and another for the poor,” said Merrick B. Garland, the U.S. attorney general.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Calls to Free Up Ukraine’s Grain Exports
item.description: Plus Biden’s Taiwan comments cause a stir in Asia and Covid hits poor countries hardest.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A farm near Lviv, Ukraine: With millions of tons of grain stuck in Ukraine, officials have warned of a global food crisis.

item.title: Henry Kissinger Suggests Ukraine Give Up Territory to Russia
item.description: The former secretary of state argued that ceding land could bring an end to the war. Critics called the idea reckless and unrealistic.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky

item.title: Ukraine Charges 8 Russian Fighters in Killings of Village Mayor and Family
item.description: The bodies of the mayor, her husband and her son were found after Russian forces retreated in early April.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: The shallow grave near Kyiv where the bodies of Olha Sukhenko, the mayor of the village of Motyzhyn, and her family were recovered last month.

item.title: U.S. Will Start Blocking Russia’s Bond Payments to American Investors
item.description: The Biden administration’s escalation of sanctions could lead to Russia’s first default on foreign debt in a century.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport and Eshe Nelson
item.media:description: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen said that Russia’s ability to borrow had already essentially been cut off.

item.title: Eager London Riders Get Up Early for Elizabeth Line’s Debut
item.description: The London subway’s sleek new Elizabeth line officially opened Tuesday, drawing train enthusiasts and awing normally stoic London commuters.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: London’s new Elizabeth line made its debut on Tuesday, opening to the public at the Liverpool Street underground station and others.

item.title: Russian Forces Pummel Key Eastern Ukraine Town
item.description: With enemy forces massed on three sides, the residents of Sievierodonetsk are at the heart of the battle.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall and Finbarr O’Reilly
item.media:credit: Finbarr O’Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Olha, a resident of Sievierodonetsk, climbing down from the ambulance that was carrying her husband on Tuesday.

item.title: Omicron Subvariant BA.2.12.1 Becomes Dominant in U.S. Virus Cases
item.description: The development comes as the United States recently began averaging more than 100,000 new confirmed cases per day again, according to a New York Times database, for the first time since February.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Benjamin Cleeton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Getting tested for the coronavirus in Syracuse, N.Y., earlier this month.

item.title: In This Small Thai Village, American History Runs Deep
item.description: In 1944, a U.S. military plane crashed in a spot the locals named “Deadman’s Torso Flat.” A team has found remains that it hopes are those of the airman.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Lauren DeCicca for The New York Times
item.media:description: Local workers digging at an excavation site in Lampang, Thailand, in March. A U.S. team was searching for the remains of an American pilot believed to have crashed there during World War II.

item.title: U.S. Birthrate Ticks Up 1 Percent, Halting a Steady Decline
item.description: Data from the federal government showed last year’s increase was the first since 2014 and followed a sharp drop in 2020, when the coronavirus pandemic hit.
item.dc:creator: Dana Goldstein and Daniel Victor
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Matthew Busch for The New York Times
item.media:description: While the birthrate went up in 2021, it is still lower than in 2019.

item.title: Russia Is Accused of Using Food as ‘Blackmail’ in Ukraine War
item.description: World leaders say there is no easy way to bypass a Russian blockade without a military clash, and accuse Vladimir V. Putin of using global hunger as a weapon.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler, Matina Stevis-Gridneff, Erika Solomon and Patricia Cohen
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A grain warehouse on the outskirts of Lviv, Ukraine.

item.title: Biden’s Words on Taiwan Leave Allies in an Awkward Spot
item.description: Ahead of a summit with Australia, India and Japan, an off-the-cuff vow to defend the island militarily against China complicates diplomacy, particularly for Australia.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:description: President Biden with, from left, Prime Minister Anthony Albanese of Australia, Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India, and Prime Minister Fumio Kishida of Japan in Tokyo on Tuesday.

item.title: Biden’s Tough Words
item.description: Gaffe or not, President Biden’s latest remark on Taiwan is consistent with his administration’s new policy.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: President Biden in Tokyo yesterday.

item.title: Russia and China Held Military Exercise in East Asia as Biden Visited
item.description: The coordinated bomber flights were the first training activity the two nations had done together since President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia ordered the invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:description: President Biden with, from left, Prime Minister Anthony Albanese of Australia, Prime Minister Fumio Kishida of Japan and Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India in Tokyo on Tuesday.

item.title: Homes for Ukrainians? The U.K. Isn’t Making It Easy
item.description: A plan that allows Britons to sponsor people fleeing the Russian invasion has been plagued by visa delays and safeguarding concerns.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.category: United Nations High Commission for Refugees
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: An event at a church in East London last week to help match Ukrainian refugees with British sponsors.

item.title: How Ukraine’s Greatest Novelist Is Fighting for His Country
item.description: Andrey Kurkov has spent his life writing about realities so absurd they defy satire. It was perfect preparation for this moment.
item.dc:creator: Giles Harvey
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Antoine d’Agata/Magnum, for The New York Times
item.media:description: Andrey Kurkov in Paris in April.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: President Biden in Asia.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: President Biden in Tokyo on Monday.

item.title: Biden Veers Off Script on Taiwan. It’s Not the First Time.
item.description: Offhand remarks that vary from the official talking points have become a feature of the Biden presidency, even as they leave his staff scrambling to spin them away afterward.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:description: President Biden’s improvisation in Tokyo stirred a mix of reactions back in Washington.

item.title: Zelensky Urges Even Harder Line on Russia as Allies Work to Remain United
item.description: A midlevel Russian diplomat broke ranks and resigned with a scathing statement on the war, and President Volodymyr Zelensky called on world leaders to turn up the pressure.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff, Anton Troianovski and Richard Pérez-Peña
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky delivering an address to the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, on Monday.

item.title: As Monkeypox Cases Rise, Nations Are Urged to Examine Vaccine Stores
item.description: The United States has stockpiled millions of doses of two smallpox vaccines, also effective against monkeypox. But the outbreaks so far are clustered in other countries.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
European Center for Disease Prevention and Control
item.media:credit: Andrea Maennel/Robert Koch Institute, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A colored scan of the monkeypox virus. As of Monday, there were more than 100 confirmed cases in 14 countries, with dozens more under investigation.

item.title: French Minister Damien Abad Is Accused of Rape by 2 Women
item.description: The women’s allegations against France’s new minister for solidarity and disabled people come amid a growing reckoning over sexist and sexually violent behavior by political figures.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: Damien Abad, the French minister for solidarity, autonomy and people with disabilities, leaving the Elysee Palace on Monday after the first new cabinet meeting.
